awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Reconstructing South American Monsoon Sensitivity to Internal and External Forcing: Reconciling Models and Tree-ring Proxies in the Central Andes
awd_abstract_narration:
The potential Broader Impacts include the potential for better understanding the South American monsoon, for filling in sparse hydroclimate records, and for fuller understanding climate variability. Collaboration with South American colleagues is planned as is extensive student involvement.

This project aims to employ classical dendrochronological techniques to generate new tropical tree-ring chronologies that are annually resolved and absolutely dated. Radiocarbon measurements (14-Carbon) will ensure accurate dating assessments. Thus, successful tree species will be selected to improve the 14-Carbon curve for the Southern Hemisphere. The resulting tree-ring series will be used to reconstruct past climate variability and regional to large--scale atmospheric dynamics for the last several centuries. The specific aims of the project are to improve understanding of: (1) the spatiotemporal variability of the South American summer monsoon (SASM); (2) long-term interactions between El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) and the SASM; and (3) the impact of volcanic forcing on past hydroclimate of the tropical Andes.

The research aims to provide significant advances in the science of tropical dendrochronology by developing a tree-ring network for the tropical Andes in Peru and Bolivia, a region with exceedingly scarce coverage of high-resolution terrestrial paleo-records. While tree rings have been extensively used in temperate climates, the tropics remain relatively unexplored due to the difficulty, in particular, of identifying consistent wood layers (tree rings) corresponding to seasonal or annual growing periods. The Central Andes are an ideal region for overcoming these difficulties, due to the pronounced precipitation seasonality and diverse forests.

The tropical Andes are a hotspot for biodiversity and its geographic position makes it extremely vulnerable to climate change. It also contains nearly all the tropical glaciers on the globe, and recent, widespread glacial retreat is causing a rapid decline in hydrological reserves.  This decline, in combination with increasing water demand due to population growth and economic expansion poses an enormous challenge for water availability, biodiversity and food security. The complex topography of the Andean Cordillera leads to a climate that is characterized by strong zonal and vertical precipitation gradients. Moisture influx from the tropical Atlantic Ocean and the Amazon basin is modulated by the SASM and ENSO. The scientific understanding of this variability is challenged by the scarcity of long instrumental observations, which also limits the ability to constrain uncertainties in future climate change projections over this region.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
To study South American Monsoon Sensitivity to internal (e.g. ENSO) and external (e.g. volcanic) forcing reliable tree-ring records are required. However, in tropical forests the lack of weather seasonality as well as tree species large diversity coupled with complex macroscopic wood anatomy tend to lead to dendrochronology dating errors, even when tree phenology shows a tendency to produce annual rings. Thus, the assessment of wood formation by an independent dating method such as radiocarbon (14C) bomb pulse dating, e.g., the matching of tree-ring chronologies obtained from traditional dendrochronological techniques with post-AD 1950 14C ages, is highly recommended. The bomb pulse reflects a rise in atmospheric 14C as a result of thermonuclear detonations in the 1950s and 1960s, which caused atmospheric 14C to nearly double its pre-bomb levels. In the case that 14C values of the tree-ring material tested agrees with the expected values from the averaged atmospheric 14C Southern and North Hemisphere curves, it can be concluded that the dendrochronological dates are correct.This approach enables independent validation of tree-ring width chronologies, ensures data quality and consistency, before broad comparisons of various paleo proxies are conducted and erroneous conclusions are drawn. Here, selected calendar years from several tree species out of sub-regions within the tropical Andes (Peru, Bolivia and Ecuador) were measured by high-precision 14C accelerator mass spectrometry at the Keck Carbon Cycle AMS (KCCAMS) facility at the University of California, Irvine (UCI) under Dr. Guaciara dos Santos (PI) supervision. Selected tree species and sites were from complete or ongoing chronologies provided by the Tree-Ring Laboratory (TRL) of the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory (LDEO) in the Palisades (NY, USA) and/or their partners from Peru, Argentina, Bolivia and Ecuador. Radiocarbon investigations were performed on 4 to 20 selected single tree rings per tree species/sites extracted to alpha cellulose by instrumentation developed at the TRL/LDEO, and by a chemical approach optimized for 14C analysis by Santos. Surprisingly, the majority of tree-ring chronologies tested here (about 18 tree species/sites in total) failed to yield the expected 14C signatures, even when cross-dating based on patterns of growth variation across trees appear plausible at first sight. For those that tree species/sites showed small or synchronized calendar year offsets (revealed by 14C analysis), tree-ring anomalies were further sorted out by wood anatomical evaluations. The updated chronologies were then retested by 14C bomb pulse dating for their consistency and reliability. Once timelines were 14C rechecked and validated, the newly appraised tree species of Polylepis microphylla, Polylepis rodolfo-vasquezii, Juglans boliviana and Prosopis alba showed some potential for dendrochronology studies, and have been reported to the community. Well-known tree species, such as Cedrela odorata, nebulosa, and fissilis, were also checked for the annual conformity. Their chronologies were confirmed and/or corrected accordingly. In sum, the high proportion of initial erroneous calendar date determinations detected in this research supports the importance of employing bomb pulse 14C dating in tropical dendrochronology and dendroecology studies.

Broader Impacts: This project provided research opportunities and training to four undergraduate students from University of California Irvine (UCI), PhD candidates and postdoctoral scholars from Tree Ring Laboratory at the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory (TRL/LDEO), as well as foreign students from Peru, Bolivia and Ecuador institutes. Undergrad students and professionals have helped on disseminating the findings of this project in lab tours and meetings (domestic and international - virtually or in-person), and participated in the products produced, as first or co-authors. So far, this award resulted in several meeting abstracts, and 4 publications (international journals). Another 2 publications are currently under review. Our findings have also been disseminated to the community through teaching the Radiocarbon Short Course (virtually; problem sets), zoom meetings, video sharing (such as, YouTube) and through lab tours to UCI students.
